tutorial.title: JSON Data Adjustment
tutorial.descriptionContent: Let's convert a JSON into a JS Object to adjust its data and then stringify it again

executableContent.instructions:
The price of the materials we use in our company has increased. So we also need to adjust the price of our products by 10%. Let's update the system!

All the information from our products is stored in a `JSON` file. Our company is using a limited system and we can only export and import this type of data. As you can see, it's difficult to see relevant information from a `JSON` string, so let's *parse* it to make it more readable and easier to make changes.

1. We've stored the json in a `jsonText` variable, now create a `jsonObject` variable that stores the parsed data.
2. Use `console.log` to print `jsonObject` to have a better view of the data structure.

files.name: script.js
files.content:
const jsonText =
  '{"orders":[{"id":"O001","product":[{"id":"P010","name":"Blue paint","price":35.00,"quantity":2},{"id":"P512","name":"Roller Brush","price":2.50,"quantity":6},{"id":"P3010","name":"Tape","price":6.50,"quantity":2}],"address":"63 Faraday Lane","payment":"Paid"},{"id":"O006","product":[{"id":"P009","name":"White Sealer","price":30.00,"quantity":4},{"id":"P512","name":"Roller Brush","price":2.50,"quantity":6},{"id":"P864","name":"Mixing Motor","price":650.90,"quantity":1},{"id":"P840","name":"Li-Ion Battery","price":145.90,"quantity":1}],"address":"1342 Lith Drive","payment":"Cash on Delivery"},{"id":"O152","product":[{"id":"P934","name":"Paint Job","price":5100.00,"quantity":1}],"address":"10 Oxy Avenue 13-478","payment":"Paid"}],"inventory":{"product":[{"id":"P010","name":"Blue paint","price":35.00,"quantity":200},{"id":"P512","name":"Roller Brush","price":2.50,"quantity":2000},{"id":"P3010","name":"Tape","price":6.50,"quantity":5000},{"id":"P009","name":"White Sealer","price":30.00,"quantity":1600},{"id":"P864","name":"Mixing Motor","price":650.90,"quantity":10},{"id":"P840","name":"Li-Ion Battery","price":145.90,"quantity":100},{"id":"P934","name":"Paint Job","price":5100.00,"quantity":99999}]}}';

lessons.title: Get specific parts of the data

executableContent.instructions:
Now we can explore the object in an easier way. We can clearly see that `jsonObject` has two main properties, `orders` and `inventory`.

1. Create a new `orders` variable and assign the `orders` data object as its value
2. Print the `orders` variable using `console.log`
3. Create a new `inventory` variable and assign the `inventory` data object as its value
4. Print the `inventory` variable using `console.log`

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint

executableContent.instructions:
You may have noticed that when we print `orders` and `inventory`, they look different than when we print `jsonObject` as a whole. Some fields are simplified as `[Array]` or `[Object]` in `jsonObject`. However, they now appear in detail in `orders` and `inventory`. This is because the deeper we dive into the data structure, the more precise details we'll get.

But let's keep going! We still have to make some changes in the `orders` and `inventory` data objects. Let's start with the `orders` object first.

We need to find the orders that have `"Cash on Delivery"` for payment type.

1. Now that you're familiar with the data structures, we can remove all the `console.log`
2. Loop through all the orders in the `orders` variable.
3. Check if the `payment` of each order is `"Cash on Delivery"` .
4. If it is, print the `product` from the `orders` in the console.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Great, we have gathered all the products from the orders that will be paid on delivery. This is important because our company is not increasing the price to orders that were paid upfront, so we just need to make changes for orders that are not paid yet.
 
1. Within the `if` condition you previously created, loop through the `product` list of the `orders`.
2. Increase the `price` of the `product` by 10%.
3. Outside the loop, print the `product` using `console.log()` to check the updated prices. Do **not** remove the `console.log()` from the previous lesson.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Note you're using two loops now. For the second loop, remember to use a different loop counter variable than the one you used in the first loop.

You can increase the price of a product by 10% by multiplying the price by `1.1`.

executableContent.instructions:
Super! Now let's do `inventory` to avoid any mismatches. Every product in the inventory needs to have its price updated.

1. We're done with `orders`, so remove all the `console.log` now.
2. After the first loop, create another loop to go through the `product` list of `inventory`.
3. Print the `price` of the `product` using `console.log`.
4. Increase the `price` of the `product` by 10%.
5. Print the `price` of the `product` using `console.log` again, you should see that the price of the product is changed.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Remember you can increase the price of an item by multiplying it by `1.1`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that the individual data objects are updated, it's time to put them back together into one data object.

1. We're done with `inventory`, so remove all the `console.log` now.
2. Create a new variable `updatedData`. It should store an object with the `orders` and `inventory` properties that use the values from our previous variables.
3. Stringify `updatedData` and set it as the value of the new variable `printData`
4. Print `printData` using `console.log`

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Stringify means to turn something into a string. We can stringify `JSON` data objects using the code below.
```
JSON.stringify(object);
```
